title: Jeremiah Chapter 46 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Jeremiah chapter 46 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Jeremiah Chapter 46 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Jeremiah Chapter 46.

questions.question: Against which nation did the word of the LORD come to Jeremiah the prophet in Jeremiah 46:1?
questions.correctAnswer: Egypt
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 46:1 introduces the prophecy against the Gentiles, specifically mentioning Egypt in verse 2.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 46:2, which king of Egypt's army was smitten by Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon?
questions.correctAnswer: Pharaohnecho
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 46:2 names Pharaohnecho as the Egyptian king whose army was defeated by Nebuchadrezzar.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 46:4, what should horsemen do before battle?
options: Harness the horses and stand forth with helmets
questions.correctAnswer: Harness the horses and stand forth with helmets
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 46:4 commands the horsemen to harness horses, stand forth with helmets, and prepare for battle.

questions.question: What does the LORD say surrounds the army that causes them to be dismayed and flee in Jeremiah 46:5?
questions.correctAnswer: Fear
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 46:5 states that fear was round about the army, causing them to be dismayed and flee.

questions.question: Where will the mighty men stumble and fall according to Jeremiah 46:6?
options: Toward the north by the river Euphrates
questions.correctAnswer: Toward the north by the river Euphrates
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 46:6 mentions the stumbling and falling of the mighty men toward the north by the river Euphrates.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 46:8, Egypt is compared to what natural phenomenon?
questions.correctAnswer: A flood
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 46:8 compares Egypt rising up like a flood whose waters are moved like rivers.

questions.question: Which peoples are called to come forth in Jeremiah 46:9 to fight alongside Egypt?
questions.correctAnswer: Ethiopians, Libyans, and Lydians
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 46:9 calls the Ethiopians, Libyans, and Lydians to come forth as mighty men to fight.

questions.question: What is described as 'a day of vengeance' in Jeremiah 46:10?
options: The day of the Lord GOD of hosts
questions.correctAnswer: The day of the Lord GOD of hosts
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 46:10 describes the day of the Lord GOD of hosts as a day of vengeance to avenge his adversaries.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 46:11, what is the daughter of Egypt told to take into Gilead?
questions.correctAnswer: Balm
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 46:11 instructs the daughter of Egypt to take balm into Gilead, though it will be in vain.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 46:15 states that the valiant men of Egypt stood firm because the LORD helped them.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 46:15 says the valiant men were swept away and did not stand because the LORD did drive them.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 46:17 indicates that Pharaoh king of Egypt is considered more than just noise.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 46:17 says Pharaoh king of Egypt is but a noise, implying insignificance.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 46:23 says the attacking army will be fewer than the grasshoppers.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 46:23 states the attackers are more than grasshoppers and are innumerable.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Jeremiah 46:19: 'O thou daughter dwelling in Egypt, furnish thyself to go into ________ : for Noph shall be waste and desolate without an inhabitant.'
questions.correctAnswer: captivity
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 46:19 explicitly says the daughter of Egypt will go into captivity.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Jeremiah 46:27: 'But fear not thou, O my servant Jacob, and be not dismayed, O Israel: for, behold, I will save thee from afar off, and thy seed from the land of their ________;'
questions.correctAnswer: captivity
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 46:27 promises saving Jacob and his seed from the land of their captivity.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 46:26, who will deliver Egypt into the hands of those that seek their lives?
questions.correctAnswer: Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 46:26 states that Nebuchadrezzar and his servants will deliver Egypt to their enemies.

medium.title: Jeremiah Chapter 46 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Jeremiah Chapter 46 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with fear about upcoming trials. Based on Jeremiah 46, what biblical truth would you share to encourage them?
options: God is with His people and will save them from captivity
Trials mean God has abandoned them
They must face trials alone without help
God allows trials but does not intervene
questions.correctAnswer: God is with His people and will save them from captivity
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 46:27-28 assures that the LORD will save His servant Jacob from captivity and will be with him, encouraging trust and courage during trials.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 46 teach about humility in facing adversity?
options: God disciplines but does not utterly abandon His people
Pride will protect you from punishment
Ignore God's warnings and rely on your own strength
God only punishes others, not His people
questions.correctAnswer: God disciplines but does not utterly abandon His people
questions.explanation: Verses 28 emphasize that God will correct His people in measure but will not leave them wholly unpunished, highlighting the need for humility and repentance.

questions.question: A believer wants to understand how to maintain faith in God's plan despite calamity. Which truth from Jeremiah 46 would you share?
options: God's vengeance on enemies also includes salvation for His people
Only good times indicate God's favor
Calamities mean God has forsaken His people
Faith is irrelevant during national troubles
questions.correctAnswer: God's vengeance on enemies also includes salvation for His people
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 46:10 and 27 show that while God brings judgment on adversaries, He promises salvation and restoration to His people, encouraging steadfast faith.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 46 instruct believers about the importance of obedience to God's word during difficult times?
options: Obedience leads to eventual restoration and peace
Obedience has no impact on trials
God ignores obedience when calamity strikes
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience leads to eventual restoration and peace
questions.explanation: Verses 27-28 indicate that despite correction, God will bring His people back to rest and ease if they remain His servants, underscoring obedience.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 46 teach about trusting God in the face of overwhelming opposition?
options: God's power surpasses enemies and He will deliver His people
Trusting in weapons is more reliable than God
People must rely solely on their own strength
questions.correctAnswer: God's power surpasses enemies and He will deliver His people
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 46:7-10 depicts God's sovereignty over nations and His power to bring judgment, encouraging believers to trust Him over worldly forces.

questions.question: A believer asks how to persevere through spiritual battles. What lesson from Jeremiah 46 would you share?
options: Prepare spiritually like warriors ready for battle
Avoid all conflict and spiritual struggle
Give up when the enemy seems strong
Rely only on human wisdom without God
questions.correctAnswer: Prepare spiritually like warriors ready for battle
questions.explanation: Verses 3-4 describe ordering shields, harnessing horses, and preparing for battle, illustrating the need for spiritual readiness and discipline.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 46 encourage believers to respond when facing shame or failure?
options: Trust God's plan despite shame and look to His restoration
Ignore God and rely on self
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God's plan despite shame and look to His restoration
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 46:12 and 24 speak of shame and captivity but also imply God's ongoing control and future deliverance, encouraging trust and repentance.

questions.question: A believer feels overwhelmed by the number of challenges they face. What biblical truth from Jeremiah 46 could bring hope?
options: God's judgment involves many enemies but His purpose is to restore His people
Challenges prove God has abandoned them
Only a few trials are allowed by God
Challenges mean they are beyond God's help
questions.correctAnswer: God's judgment involves many enemies but His purpose is to restore His people
questions.explanation: Verses 23 and 26 describe many enemies but affirm God's plan to restore the land and His people afterward, offering hope amid adversity.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 46 teaches that God will completely destroy His people without any hope of correction or restoration.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 46:28 clearly states God will correct but not utterly destroy His people, showing His mercy and commitment to restoration.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 46 shows that trusting in human strength alone leads to victory.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verses 15 and 21 indicate that the valiant men were swept away because the LORD drove them, teaching reliance on God rather than human strength.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jeremiah 46:27 encourages believers not to be dismayed because God will save ______ from captivity.
questions.correctAnswer: Jacob
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 46:27 comforts by promising that God will save Jacob (representing Israel) from captivity, encouraging trust and hope.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 46 guide believers in maintaining integrity during times of national or personal crisis?
options: Trust in God’s justice and live obediently despite adversity
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in God’s justice and live obediently despite adversity
questions.explanation: Verses 25-28 show God’s justice on nations but also calls for His people’s obedience and trust, encouraging integrity and faithfulness.

questions.question: What does the imagery of horses and chariots in Jeremiah 46:9 teach about spiritual preparation?
options: Believers must actively equip themselves for spiritual battle
Warfare is only physical, not spiritual
questions.correctAnswer: Believers must actively equip themselves for spiritual battle
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 46:9 calls horses and chariots to rage, symbolizing the need for believers to be prepared and equipped spiritually for trials.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 46, how should believers respond when witnessing God’s judgment on others?
options: Trust in God’s justice but remember His mercy toward His own
Assume they are exempt from correction
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in God’s justice but remember His mercy toward His own
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 46:10 and 27 show God’s judgment on enemies but also His salvation for His people, teaching balanced trust and humility.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 46 encourage believers to remain content and grateful in the midst of God’s correction?
options: By trusting that correction leads to restoration and peace
By questioning God’s fairness without hope
By focusing only on present suffering
questions.correctAnswer: By trusting that correction leads to restoration and peace
questions.explanation: Verses 27-28 emphasize that God’s correction is measured and leads to rest and ease, encouraging contentment and gratitude despite trials.

hard.title: Jeremiah Chapter 46 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Jeremiah Chapter 46.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 46, which enemy king is specifically mentioned as striking Egypt at the river Euphrates in Carchemish?
questions.correctAnswer: Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 46:2 states that Nebuchadrezzar king of Babylon smote the army of Pharaoh Necho by the river Euphrates in Carchemish.

questions.question: The battle imagery in Jeremiah 46:3-4 employs which types of ancient Near Eastern military equipment?
options: Buckler, shield, horses, helmets, spears, brigandines
Sling, sling stones, chariots, bows, arrows
questions.correctAnswer: Buckler, shield, horses, helmets, spears, brigandines
questions.explanation: Verses 3 and 4 mention buckler, shield, horses, helmets, spears, and brigandines as part of the battle preparations, reflecting the armor and weapons used in Jeremiah’s historical context.

questions.question: What literary device is predominantly used in Jeremiah 46:7-8 to describe Egypt's military threat?
options: Simile comparing Egypt to a flood and rivers
Allegory of a shepherd and sheep
questions.correctAnswer: Simile comparing Egypt to a flood and rivers
questions.explanation: Verse 8 uses similes: Egypt is likened to a flood and its waters to rivers to express the overwhelming military force and threat.

questions.question: Jeremiah 46:10 refers to 'the day of the Lord GOD of hosts' as a day of what?
questions.correctAnswer: Vengeance and sacrifice
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 46:10 explicitly calls it a day of vengeance when the LORD avenges his adversaries and the sword is satiated with blood.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 46:11, what is the significance of the 'balm' in Gilead for Egypt?
options: It is futile medicine that will not cure Egypt’s wounds
It symbolizes healing and restoration for Egypt
It refers to a treaty of alliance
questions.correctAnswer: It is futile medicine that will not cure Egypt’s wounds
questions.explanation: Verse 11 uses the balm of Gilead metaphorically to highlight that despite Egypt’s attempts at remedies, it will not be healed.

questions.question: Which peoples are listed in Jeremiah 46:9 as coming to aid Egypt’s army?
questions.correctAnswer: Ethiopians, Libyans, and Lydians
questions.explanation: Verse 9 explicitly names Ethiopians, Libyans, and Lydians as mighty men coming to Egypt’s military aid.

questions.question: The phrase in Jeremiah 46:15, 'Why are thy valiant men swept away?', implies what about Egypt’s military strength?
options: It was overcome because the LORD drove them away
They were victorious and stood firm
They formed a strong alliance with Babylon
Their downfall was due to internal betrayal
questions.correctAnswer: It was overcome because the LORD drove them away
questions.explanation: Verse 15 states the valiant men did not stand because the LORD drove them, indicating divine judgment caused their defeat.

questions.question: Jeremiah 46:18 uses the mountains Tabor and Carmel as similes for what aspect of the prophecy?
options: The certainty and grandeur of the LORD’s coming
The fleeting nature of Babylon’s power
questions.correctAnswer: The certainty and grandeur of the LORD’s coming
questions.explanation: The verse compares the LORD’s coming to the enduring and prominent mountains Tabor and Carmel, emphasizing certainty and majesty.

questions.question: What is the historical and cultural significance of the cities Migdol, Noph, and Tahpanhes mentioned in Jeremiah 46:14?
options: They were key Egyptian border fortresses vulnerable to Babylonian attack
They were Babylonian cities allied with Egypt
They were centers of Egyptian religious worship
questions.correctAnswer: They were key Egyptian border fortresses vulnerable to Babylonian attack
questions.explanation: These cities were strategically important Egyptian strongholds on the frontier, making them significant in the context of Babylonian invasion.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 46:20-23, how does the LORD describe the invading army against Egypt?
options: As innumerable as grasshoppers, marching like serpents, cutting down forests
As a gentle stream bringing peace and renewal
As a single mighty warrior defeating all foes
As a flock of sheep seeking pasture
questions.correctAnswer: As innumerable as grasshoppers, marching like serpents, cutting down forests
questions.explanation: Verses 22-23 describe the invaders with vivid imagery: their voice like a serpent, multitude like grasshoppers, and destructive like wood hewers.

questions.question: Jeremiah 46:25-26 reveals God's judgment upon Egypt and its gods. How does this reflect the broader biblical theme of divine sovereignty?
options: God punishes Egypt and their gods, showing He is supreme over false deities
It suggests Egypt’s gods are equal to the God of Israel
It promises Egypt will conquer Babylon
It calls for Egypt to be worshipped alongside Israel’s God
questions.correctAnswer: God punishes Egypt and their gods, showing He is supreme over false deities
questions.explanation: These verses affirm the LORD’s supremacy by judging Egypt and their gods, a common biblical theme regarding God’s sovereignty over nations and idols.

questions.question: In Jeremiah 46:27-28, what is the promised future for Jacob (Israel) despite the surrounding nations’ destruction?
options: Jacob will be saved, restored, and not completely destroyed
Jacob will face total annihilation like the other nations
Jacob will abandon the land and wander
questions.correctAnswer: Jacob will be saved, restored, and not completely destroyed
questions.explanation: Verses 27-28 promise deliverance and restoration for Israel, emphasizing God’s covenant faithfulness even amid judgment.

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 46 foreshadow the later Babylonian exile described in 2 Kings and 2 Chronicles?
options: By predicting Nebuchadrezzar’s victory over Egypt and captivity of nations
By foretelling the fall of Assyria to Egypt
By describing a peaceful alliance between Israel and Egypt
By recounting the rebuilding of Jerusalem’s temple
questions.correctAnswer: By predicting Nebuchadrezzar’s victory over Egypt and captivity of nations
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 46 prophesies Babylon’s military dominance foreshadowing the exile events recorded in later historical books.

questions.question: True or False: Jeremiah 46 uses typology by presenting Pharaoh as a symbol of worldly power that ultimately falls before God's sovereignty.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The chapter typifies Pharaoh and Egypt as human empires subject to God’s judgment, illustrating the biblical theme of divine supremacy over earthly powers.

questions.question: The Hebrew term translated 'buckler' in Jeremiah 46:3 suggests what about the nature of the defensive equipment?
options: It was a small, round shield used for close combat
It was a large, wooden siege engine
It referred to a helmet ornament
It was a type of spear
questions.correctAnswer: It was a small, round shield used for close combat
questions.explanation: The Hebrew term for 'buckler' indicates a compact shield, emphasizing the detailed military imagery used to prepare for battle.

theological.title: Jeremiah Chapter 46 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Jeremiah Chapter 46 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the primary theme of Jeremiah 46?
options: The prophecy against Egypt and its defeat
questions.correctAnswer: The prophecy against Egypt and its defeat
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 46:2 clearly introduces the prophecy against Egypt and its army defeated by Babylon. This theme is consistent with other prophetic judgments such as Isaiah 19 and Ezekiel 30, showing God's sovereign control over nations. The defeat also aligns with Old Testament judgment motifs (Psalm 2:4-5) and the New Testament teaching on God's sovereignty over history (Romans 9:17).

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 46, who is the king of Babylon that smites Egypt?
questions.correctAnswer: Nebuchadrezzar
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 46:2 and 46:13 identify Nebuchadrezzar as the king of Babylon who defeats Egypt. This historical figure is also mentioned in Daniel 1:1-2 and 2:1-49, showing God’s use of Babylon to execute judgment. Theologically, this demonstrates God's providence over empires (Daniel 4:17, Romans 13:1).

questions.question: What imagery is used to describe Egypt's power in Jeremiah 46?
options: A flood with moving waters like rivers
A lion roaring in the wilderness
questions.correctAnswer: A flood with moving waters like rivers
questions.explanation: Verses 7 and 8 employ flood imagery to describe Egypt’s military power, highlighting both its strength and impending judgment. Flood imagery is often used in Scripture to depict overwhelming forces (Genesis 7:17-18, Isaiah 59:19). The judgment on Egypt as a flood is parallel to God's control over the elements (Psalm 29:10) and His power to subdue nations (Revelation 17:15).

questions.question: What day is described in Jeremiah 46:10, and what does it signify?
options: The day of the Lord God of hosts, a day of vengeance
The day of creation, a day of blessing
The day of rest, a day of peace
The day of harvest, a day of plenty
questions.correctAnswer: The day of the Lord God of hosts, a day of vengeance
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 46:10 describes the day of the Lord as a day of vengeance where God executes judgment on His adversaries. This eschatological theme is consistent with other prophetic writings (Joel 2:31, Zephaniah 1:14-18, 1 Thessalonians 5:2) and the New Testament's teaching on Christ’s return as judge (2 Thessalonians 1:6-8).

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 46:11 say about the healing of Egypt?
options: Many medicines will be used in vain; Egypt will not be cured
Egypt will be healed completely by the balm
Egypt will find healing through repentance
Egypt will be healed by its allies
questions.correctAnswer: Many medicines will be used in vain; Egypt will not be cured
questions.explanation: The verse reveals that Egypt’s attempts to heal its wounds are futile, symbolizing the inevitability of divine judgment. This aligns with Scripture's teaching on the hardness of human hearts in sin (Romans 1:18-21, Hebrews 3:13-15) and the finality of God’s righteous judgment (Hebrews 10:26-31).

questions.question: In Jeremiah 46, what reason is given for the valiant men of Egypt being swept away?
questions.correctAnswer: Because the LORD drove them
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 46:15 states that the valiant men did not stand because the Lord drove them away, emphasizing God's sovereignty over battles and human affairs (Exodus 14:25, 1 Samuel 17:47, Psalm 33:10-11). This theological truth affirms that human power is subordinate to divine will.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 46:17 say about Pharaoh king of Egypt?
options: He is but a noise and has passed the appointed time
He is the mightiest king of the earth
He will repent and be restored
questions.correctAnswer: He is but a noise and has passed the appointed time
questions.explanation: This verse highlights the futility and imminent end of Pharaoh's power, indicating divine timing in judgment. The motif of appointed times is significant in biblical eschatology (Ecclesiastes 3:1, Daniel 2:21, Acts 1:7), reinforcing God's control over history and rulers.

questions.question: What promise is given to Jacob (Israel) in the latter part of Jeremiah 46?
options: He will be saved from captivity and live in rest and ease
He will be destroyed along with the nations
He will conquer all nations by his own strength
questions.correctAnswer: He will be saved from captivity and live in rest and ease
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 46:27 promises salvation and restoration for Jacob, showing God’s covenant faithfulness. This connects to the broader biblical narrative of Israel’s redemption (Isaiah 43:1-3, Ezekiel 37:21-22, Romans 11:26) and God's ultimate plan for His people’s salvation in Christ (Romans 11:26-27).

questions.question: How does Jeremiah 46 describe the multitude coming against Egypt?
options: Like grasshoppers, innumerable and cutting down forests
questions.correctAnswer: Like grasshoppers, innumerable and cutting down forests
questions.explanation: Verses 22-23 use the metaphor of grasshoppers to depict a vast, destructive army. This imagery is consistent with Joel 1:4 and 2:25, where locusts symbolize God’s judgment. It reflects God’s sovereign control over nations and the certainty of His judgment (Revelation 9:3-10).

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 46:25 say God will punish?
options: The multitude of No, Pharaoh, Egypt, their gods, and kings
questions.correctAnswer: The multitude of No, Pharaoh, Egypt, their gods, and kings
questions.explanation: This verse reveals the comprehensive nature of divine judgment on Egypt and its idolatry, including their gods and rulers. This reflects the biblical teaching on God’s judgment of idols and false gods (Exodus 12:12, Isaiah 46:1-2, 1 Corinthians 8:4-6) and the sovereignty of the true God (Psalm 96:5).

questions.question: What assurance does God give to Israel in Jeremiah 46:28 about the nations where He has driven them?
options: He will make a full end of all those nations but will correct Israel in measure
He will join Israel with those nations
He will make Israel like those nations
questions.correctAnswer: He will make a full end of all those nations but will correct Israel in measure
questions.explanation: This verse teaches God’s perfect justice: nations opposing Israel will be fully judged, but Israel will be disciplined, not destroyed. This concept aligns with God’s covenant faithfulness and discipline (Hebrews 12:5-11, Deuteronomy 8:5, Lamentations 3:31-33, Romans 11:22), showing God’s mercy and holiness.

questions.question: What military preparations are described in Jeremiah 46:3-4?
options: Order the buckler and shield, harness horses, and prepare horsemen with helmets and spears
Build walls and dig trenches around the city
Pray for peace and seek alliances
Send envoys to Nebuchadrezzar for mercy
questions.correctAnswer: Order the buckler and shield, harness horses, and prepare horsemen with helmets and spears
questions.explanation: Verses 3 and 4 describe detailed military preparations symbolizing human efforts in war. This emphasizes the reality of conflict and human agency under God’s sovereign will (Psalm 20:7, Proverbs 21:31, Isaiah 31:1), highlighting that even in battle God is ultimately in control.

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 46:6 say about the swift and mighty men during the battle?
options: They shall stumble and fall toward the north by the river Euphrates
They shall conquer all their enemies
questions.correctAnswer: They shall stumble and fall toward the north by the river Euphrates
questions.explanation: This verse declares that no one, however swift or mighty, will escape God's judgment. It reflects the biblical principle that human strength cannot overcome divine will (Job 9:12, Psalm 33:10, Nahum 1:15), affirming God’s sovereignty over victory and defeat.

questions.question: Who are mentioned as coming with Egypt’s army in Jeremiah 46:9?
questions.correctAnswer: Ethiopians, Libyans, and Lydians
questions.explanation: Verse 9 lists these groups as allies or mercenaries in Egypt’s army, showing the widespread nature of alliances. This reflects biblical descriptions of the nations surrounding Israel (Genesis 10, Ezekiel 30:4-5) and God’s judgment on all nations (Revelation 16:12-16).

questions.question: What does Jeremiah 46:19 prophesy about Noph?
options: It shall be waste and desolate without an inhabitant
It shall prosper and become a great city
It shall be rebuilt and fortified
It shall be the refuge of many
questions.correctAnswer: It shall be waste and desolate without an inhabitant
questions.explanation: This verse predicts the desolation of Noph, symbolizing the complete devastation of Egypt’s cities due to judgment. This is consistent with Old Testament prophecies of desolation upon sin (Isaiah 13:19-22, Ezekiel 30:13, Jeremiah 25:12) and New Testament warnings about judgment (Matthew 24:35-36).
